Helpfu

review_title: Stuck in yesteryear - in dire need of house cleaning
pros: Numerous "smart" employees with vast amounts of problem solving abilities and "think outside the box" approaches to daily tasks and troubleshooting scenarios. In my time at the company, I encountered many employees that believed in the mission of the company and that were driven by a goal to learn and better their performance output. A majority of these employees were motivated towards vertical movement while also wanting to elevate the performance of those around them - team effort and team rewards (see cons for flip side). Most start work without a "me" mentality and are dedicated to the big picture.
cons:
Management consists of individual protection silos, and a culture conducive towards "kick the can down the road" when it comes to employee well being and dealing with intra-company and intra-departmental issues. In my experience, team leadership was selfishly motivated as supervisors/directors appeared to place blame on employees within their group while taking credit for team contributions. 

Opportunities for vertical movement seemed stagnant within numerous teams, forcing many to form their own silo to protect their own job.

A culture that was clearly averse to accepting the changes within the modern workforce - stuck in the late 80s/early 90s when it comes to workforce mentality.

The company has a massive problem with nepotism and favoritism. 

Use of isolation tactics against "new thinking". 

Fully embracing of the "good ol' boy" culture.

Discouraging atmosphere for those looking to grow their career, and even more discouraging to young employees set on not being "boxed in" to a simple job title or description.

Numerous mid/upper-level managers are in dire need of corporate leadership training, as well as a fresh course on HR policies and modern day business practices. Training employees in Microsoft programs does not qualify as company sponsored training.

Extremely low base salaries = severely underpaid talent (especially given the fluid formulas used for bonus payouts - read "change as necessary"). 

Work/Life balance sold as a pro in the interview process... this is not true based on the stories I've heard, or my experience.

Many of these "cons" have been ongoing for over a decade. Each passing month of accepting the status-quo is a month closer to passing the line of no return.
Advice to Management
Catch up to the 2000s - there is a reason employees under the age of 40 aren't sticking around, and the problem isn't those employees. The core of the company is incredible... but the well has been poisoned, and a blind eye turned. There are numerous employees with incredible leadership potential that are stuck in the waiting behind managers that severely lack the qualities needed for their job.
Helpful (7
advice_to_mgmt: Catch up to the 2000s - there is a reason employees under the age of 40 aren't sticking around, and the problem isn't those employees. The core of the company is incredible... but the well has been poisoned, and a blind eye turned. There are numerous employees with incredible leadership potential that are stuck in the waiting behind managers that severely lack the qualities needed for their job.

pros:
Coworkers are nice people - company wide. Can't say enough nice things about them. 
Drama is minimal and discouraged. 
Previous management was very balance of life oriented, that may change with the new management.
cons:
The new management is short term oriented. 
The layoffs are throwing out experienced personnel to reduce the overall average age of the workforce - this is troubling.
Many management actions taken recently strongly appear to be preparing the company to be sold and unconcerned about long term damage for short term gains. 
Nepotism runs deep.
Some people are too vocal about their politics.
Advice to Management
Layoffs have depleted the knowledge base and have cut too deeply. 
Managers should be required to have their reports attend training and advance their skill set, not just company sponsored training on MS Office but real career enhancing skills. 
The culture of the company is what sets it apart from nearly all other companies, and it is in jeopardy as a direct result of the new management. People are scared and demoralized. 
Nepotism should be eliminated.

review_title: Good company, but facing significant issues
pros: Great people, both employees and management. Upper management is communicative and takes care of employees. Higher middle management tends to be very competent and attentive to employees at all levels. Benefits are good, schedule (half fridays and flexible hours) is great.
cons:
Lower and middle management is a mixed bag - some are great, others are competent in the roles that they supervise, but terrible at managing. Company as a whole has a tendency towards being "penny wise, pound foolish" in regards to everything from project management to benefits and compensation. Rigid on non-financial compensation (increased PTO, regular work from home) even in an environment where it could increase morale at no cost to the company. HR loves to nickle and dime employees on PTO hours even when that employee's manager approves.
Advice to Management
Look at why so many mid-level employees are leaving. 

Many have been with the company for years, not just the stereotype of "join for two years of training and jump ship". The combination of ineffective supervisors, flat salaries, slashed bonuses, and a long-term incentive plan that has been gutted means that there often isn't much reason to stay when other companies are hiring.
Helpful (6

review_title: Not a great place to work
pros: Great health benefits and work-life balance. Most people are nice and pleasant to work with.
cons:
No people development. Managers not trained to be effective as managers. Culture is based on who you know and the time you have spent there, not on performance or ideas. This is not a results-oriented or idea-driven culture. Lots of protective silos and minimal cross-functional collaboration. Terrible place for millennials (I'm not one, but I have worked with several)...most are unhappy and looking to leave.
Advice to Management
Need to be more results-oriented in the operations side of the business. Corporate IT needs to mature; it's far too outdated and is dragging down performance relative to peers. Need to implement a millennial-retention strategy soon or there will not be anyone to take over when the veterans retire.

review_title: Beware of your surroundings and trust NO ONE!!
pros: Half days on Friday are great. The company pays for metro passes if you live near a park and ride. They also pay for parking but practically force the bus on you. There were some really nice people in other departments. The company as a whole looked great and was somewhere I wanted to be for the long haul.
cons:
My department was vicious. Everyone plots against each other, acting like best friends. Very cut throat. The gossip is vicious, profane, VERY PERSONAL, and unlike anything I've ever seen in a professional environment. They hate new people and treat them like they are disposable. Jealousy is an epidemic because everyone wants to be the center of attention and can't stand others getting recognition. If an employee doesn't like someone and the employee is a favorite, they aggressively go after the person's job, are hostile, argumentative, confrontational often yelling at the person, and lie about them to the manager. Brown nosing gets you everywhere! The manager allows it and brags about how many people have been fired. If an employee reports someone, they WILL be retaliated against. Managers and employees talk /gossip behind closed doors and managers never let the target know there is a real problem or ask for their side. They don't want new ideas and if you make the slightest mistake, management publicly ridicules you in front of your co-workers. There is no such thing as constructive feedback. One insignificant mistake will get a person fired if they're not in the group of favorites or are new. They'll never see it coming. They'd rather replace someone than work with them and make the rest of the team act like adults. I saw this happen time and time again, always the same employees, while I was there until I finally had to leave. It is truly a toxic work environment.
Advice to Management
Stay out of the gossip. You're their manager. They are your subordinates. Value new employees. Recognize cut throat behavior and do not tolerate bullying and retaliation. If someone makes a mistake the first time they do something, realize they are human. If there is a problem worth firing someone for, they should be coached privately and given an opportunity to improve. Show some respect! Upper management should really check to see how their managers are really managing their teams. When everyone is reporting each other to HR, there might be a problem!! When there are screaming matches happening at people's desks, a manager is failing. When a manager is constantly firing new people, it is worth looking into. That's not normal. Pay attention!!
Helpful (8

cons:

If it was not for a particular supervisor I probably never would have left the company. I was the 13th employee to leave the office in an 18 month period because of the previously mentioned supervisor.

Stop micro managing and do not violate the trust of employees. Watching employees work from your pickup while it is snowing out isn't going to earn you any loyalty either. I'd take a long hard look at the Rocky Mountain District if I were the president of the company.

review_title: DRIVERS TOOK A H U G E PAY CUT!!! OVER 35% !!!
pros: GOOD BENEFITS! That's about it anymore...
cons:
They keep telling us the DRIVERS are the most important employees. The biggest ASSET to the company. So how come when the industry entered the downturn ONLY the DRIVERS took a 25% hourly pay cut, a 50% PLUS cut to our quarterly bonus, Lost almost ALL of our EXCESS LOADING and UNLOADING PAY, went from 5 on 2 off-- to 4 on 2 off, effectively cutting us from 20 pay days per month to 18 per month AND ALSO we get ONLY 1 load a day for 2 of the 4 days some pay cycles! To put it another way >$100,000.00+ a year to <$45,000.00 a YEAR AND THEY WON'T LAY ANYONE OFF! THIS FORCES YOU TO QUIT OR GO BROKE, and if you quit, they keep your last bonus (because you have to wait 2-1/2 months AFTER it is earned, before you get it!) and the $1500 they give you at sign on, so you don't even get a final paycheck. 
They care about the drivers...HA!
 If they cared about the drivers the MANAGEMENT WOULD TAKE A PAY CUT, OFFICE WORKERS, MECHANICS, EVERYONE would have to "Sacrifice". But NOPE-ONLY THE DRIVERS!
Advice to Management
GET RID OF ABOUT HALF OF THE NEEDLESS OFFICE STAFF, CUT OUT THE BONUS'S FROM MANAGEMENT, GIVE YOURSELVES A PAY CUT and GIVE THE ONLY PEOPLE WHO ACTUALLY ARE AN ASSET (Rather than an expense) THE PAY WE DESERVE, AND EARN!

pros:
Good benefits, medical, dental, vision, 401K
Good with flexible work schedules
Quarterly updates are beneficial for a pulse on what is going on
Pay is good at the beginning. 
Long term incentive program is good
cons:
Tribal culture: you are either part of the tribe or not. If you are not, be ready to justify even the smallest decision that is made. 
Upper management has the tendency to dive down into insignificant level of detail simply to find a flaw that is later used as a jab against you and your performance. Upper management does not deliver compliments only critical feedback which makes it difficult to maintain a positive outlook on how you are doing.

Speed to market and lowest cost are paramount to safety and functionality for most projects. 
Action from other departments can be slow unless the request is made by a senior manager in many cases. This results in inefficiencies in execution of work which will be blamed on the individual not the system or lack of resources. 
 Strong resistance to diverse points of view to try new ideas or new service providers

A methodical approach to projects while slower always proves to be the lowest total cost option however, here the preference is to go fast, bolt on as you go and blame everyone else for why the total cost is higher than what was forecasted. 

Has a small company mentality but is now sufficiently large enough that processes need to be upgraded or changed to accommodate growth.
Advice to Management
Old management style of managing by exception is not effective in retaining top talent. Micromanagement breeds distrust in the organization thus decreasing motivation. It is okay to provide constructive feedback as long as it is justified and not in the form of an attack on the individuals previous experience. Diversity of industry experience is useful for providing a cold eye prospective to old problems. Don't discount these ideas simply because they are different from what has historically been done.

review_title: Good place to work, but still under paid according to industry standard.
pros: Pay is ok, get to work inside away from the elements , some what of a relaxed environment but even that is beginning to change.
cons:
Where do I start? The pay is not up to industry standards even though management wants you to feel like you should be grateful you even get a paycheck. The competition has a way better benefits package with some still offering pensions. Other companies have their control center located closer to a bigger city with more things to do whereas the Plains control center is located in Midland Texas. Nothing to do, and one of the most expensive places to live with subpar pay!!!
Advice to Management
Bump up the pay to compete with the competition!!! Increase benefits to compete with the competition! !!! Remember that the Permian Basin is one of the highest cost of living areas in Texas. Why stay in Midland with nothing to do, get less pay with less benefits in a high cost of living town when a person go go to Dallas, San Antonio, or Houston and get better pay, better benefits and all with a lower cost of living. Think people think! !

review_title: District Manager lied about compensation; new management will not hold up the bargain.
pros: Above-average benefits. Less-than-average micromanagement. Some PPE reimbursed.
cons:
Like others said, lower pay than the competition. The benefits are good but you cannot eat them! Keeping the job here until I find an hourly replacement. The local competition pays 30% more. The company is buying up lots of capital assets but they are CUTTING driver income! Perhaps they think training expenses and lost productivity are preferable to keeping good drivers...
Advice to Management
They're not listening, so what is the point? This is NOT a good attitude to ignore in your employees driving 80,000 pounds on public roads...

review_title: Great company, with great job security.
pros:
- very nice people
- great work morale
- great computer systems (information is readily available all the time)
- great inner company incentives. (raffles, and ticket giveaways etc)
cons:
- management sometimes doesn't tell you what they think of your work, or lack of work.
- Would rather talk behind closed doors with your co-workers about why they dont like the work you are giving, but cannot give you feedback themselves.

(In the Accounting Dept)
Advice to Management
Accounts Receivable: Talk to your employees about what they are doing right and wrong. Have more communication than "how are you?" Talk to people about what they can do better, and why they aren't getting the more challenging work, or why they are getting more challenging work. TALK TO YOUR EMPLOYEES.

employee_status: Operations Coordinator in Long Beach, CA
pros: If you are not concerned with career opprtinites and money is the only thing that matters to you then Plains is the place for you. Plains purchased our comapny and quickly threw money at us to move to Texas. There were many openings were some of us could have filled and stayed in California. Instead they hired people from the outside filling those vacancies clearly knownig that 95% of us did not want to leave. Many good people left and others went to Texas with the intention to come back. When Plains would find out you were trying to come back they would throw more money at you. When you rip families apart money is not the answer.
cons:
bad management and no career opportunities
Advice to Management
look at talent first before looking at frindships

pros: good compensation, bonus plan is satisfactory. very intelligent senior management, aggressive acquisition strategy. The company is willing to take risks in order to increase profitability.
cons:
Promotions are difficult to come by. Transfers within departments are possible but relatively rare. Lots of political issues to navigate in the Director level and above.
Advice to Management
Work to more actively grow employees, promote from within in order to keep the knowledge in house, instead of hiring from outside so often. Most departments seem to have too much management level, not enough employees. Departments are too lean so the workload is too heavy, yet the expectations keep increasing.
